title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that drug use in the United States is significant, with millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively. The cultivation and trafficking of these drugs in these countries lead to violence, instability, and corruption. Additionally, drug trafficking in transit countries poses a threat to law enforcement, political institutions, citizen security, and US interests. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in 2008 alone. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the US for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities. US counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean totaled $11.3 billion from 1980-2008. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction in the Western Hemisphere. Its purpose is to identify policy options to improve existing counternarcotics policies. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction. It will assess international drug control policies, interdiction efforts, economic development alternatives, technology deployment against drug cartels, and efforts to curb chemical precursor trafficking. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess efforts to curb chemical precursor trafficking for illicit drugs, the effectiveness of US drug certification process, the demand for illicit drugs in the US population, drug prevention and treatment programs, and recommendations to improve US policies on reducing illicit drug supply and demand. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess ways to improve US policies on reducing illicit drug supply and demand, including consulting with various leaders and organizations in the region. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a report to various committees and officials detailing its recommendations, findings, and conclusions within 12 months of its first meeting. The ONDCP report will include recommendations, findings, and conclusions from the Commission, as well as input from leaders and organizations consulted. The report will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the Commission's duration, with vacancies filled promptly. Appointments must be made within 30 days, and an initial meeting to plan the review process must occur within 60 days of enactment. The Commission shall hold an initial meeting to develop a schedule for the review and report, selecting a Chairperson. Six members constitute a quorum. Members receive travel expenses as per regulations while performing Commission services. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold meetings, conduct hearings, and access necessary resources from various government agencies to fulfill its duties. The General Services Administration will provide office space and administrative support for the Commission's activities. The Commission has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts with Federal and State agencies, private firms, institutions, and individuals for necessary activities. Contracts entered into by the Commission cannot extend beyond its termination date. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff and experts. Staff compensation shall not exceed level IV of the Executive Schedule, and experts can be hired temporarily under specific regulations. The Executive Director of the Commission can procure temporary services with approval, and Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission without fiscal year limitation. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission to Congress.
